newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatia offers ex-Serb public property for sale.
newsitem.headline: Croatia offers ex-Serb public property for sale.

text.p: Croatia has opened a public tender for the sale of 51 holiday resorts on its Adriatic coast which were previously owned by state-run companies from Serbia and Montenegro, Slobodna Dalmacija daily said on Thursday.
The Privatisation Fund's reserve price for 36,000 square metres of facilities located along the coast and on islands totals almost 31 million marks ($16.5 million).

State-run companies from other former Yugoslav republics, including Serbia and Montenegro, owned rest and recreation facilities on the Adriatic coast before Croatia's 1991 bid for independence and the ensuing Serb-Croat war.

During the war, both sides expropriated each other's firms. The facilites owned by Serbian and Montenegrin firms became Croatian government property following a 1992 act. The act did not include private property.
All bidders must enclose a guarantee by a leading Croatian or European bank.
The tender has been recently published in Croatian newspapers and closes on September 2. -- Zagreb newsroom +385 1 455 7075 ($ = 1.882 German Marks)
